Monsoon Rain in Pakistan

Heavy monsoon rains have caused flash floods, landslides, house collapses, and drownings across Pakistan from 26 June 2025 to date. The worst-affected provinces are Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Punjab,AJK, Sindh and  Balochistan, with deaths, injuries, infrastructure damage, Dam collapse, and livestock losses reported.

The  most recent spell of rain has poured almost without pause across parts of Punjab province since the afternoon of 16 July 2025, causing flooding. According to the national disaster management authority reports, the rececnt spell of rain has caused damges and resulted more deaths and injuries alongside infrastruture damages. Furthermore, the Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) has warned that another strong monsoon weather system will hit most parts of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa in the next few days, while Punjab is expected to receive heavy showers.

Damages Detail Since 26th June 2026:

  • Cumulative (26th June to 18th July 2025):

    • 193 deaths: 64 males, 36 females, 93 children
    • 544 injured: 217 males, 154 females, 173 children
     

  • Infrastructure Damage From 26th June to 18th July 2025:

    • 689 houses damaged (163 Fully and 526 Partically).
    • Roads destroyed in Swat, Upper Dir, Kurram (KP), and Shigar (GB), Sindh, Punjab, Balochistan, and isolating communities
    • Water reservoir (Dam) collapse in Chakwal, Punjab 
    • The bridge was partially destroyed in KPK, Sindh, Punjab and Baluchistan
    • 193 Livestock Perished in all Provinces
    • 3013 different relief items have been distributed by the NDMA and PDMA in different provinces.

Heavy monsoon rains have caused flash floods, landslides, house collapses, and drownings across Pakistan. The worst-affected provinces are Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP) Punjab,AJK, Sindh and Balochistan, with casualties, injuries, infrastructure damage, and livestock losses reported.

  • Cumulative (26th to 29th June):

    • 78 deaths: 25 males, 16 females, 37 children
    • 136 injured: 47 males, 34 females, 55 children
     

  • Infrastructure Damage (Last 24 Hours):

    • 185 houses were fully damaged in KP, Sindh, and Balochistan
    • Roads destroyed in Kurram (KP) and Shigar (GB), Swat, Upper Dir, and Sindh, isolating communities
    • The bridge was partially destroyed in KPK, Sindh, and Baluchistan
    • 91 livestock killed in Sindh
 

2. Current Context

Monsoon rains since 26 June 2025 have triggered severe flash floods, especially in hilly areas. Rescue operations have saved 135 people , mainly in KP. Relief material distribution remains limited.

 

3. Affected Population

Residents of Punjab (Attock), KP (Mansehra, Swat, Bunner, Kurram), Balochistan (Zhob, Harnai), and Sindh (Tharparkar, Mirpurkhas) and Balochistan are most affected. Tourists in flood-prone areas like Swat are also at risk.

 

4. Impact on Population

  • Loss of Lives and Injuries: Women and children disproportionately affected; one family from Multan was swept away in Zhob.
  • Housing Damage: Thousands face shelter insecurity.(NDMA 185 Houses Fully Dameged)
  • Livelihood Losses: Livestock deaths impact rural economies.
  • Health Risks: Lack of medical care and clean water increases disease risk.
  • Transport Disruption: Washed-away roads delay aid delivery and isolate communities.

results.name: PAK: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 07-2025 - Flash Flood
results.summary:
Torrential rainfall triggered severe flooding in the River Swat, causing rapid inundation of adjacent areas and resulting in a devastating human toll with 7 confirmed deaths, 6 persons reported missing, and 62 individuals successfully rescued. The floodwaters caused significant damage to critical infrastructure, including roads and bridges, which has isolated communities, though the full scale of destruction remains under assessment. Currently, 75 persons remain trapped in affected areas, with evacuation efforts actively ongoing by the goverment.  

In Dir Upper District, a sudden flash flood struck Kumrat Valley (Tehsil Kalkot) on June 21, 2025, leading to 1 fatality and 20 injuries, ranging from minor to moderate. The disaster has severely impacted livelihoods, destroying 273 kanals of crops, including maize and potatoes, and resulting in the loss of 70 livestock. Critical infrastructure has suffered extensive damage, with 30 houses fully destroyed and 120 partially damaged, alongside the complete disruption of 40 drinking water schemes and 9 irrigation channels spanning 4,000 feet. Additionally, 1 school and 4 pedestrian bridges have been rendered non-functional, further exacerbating the challenges faced by affected communities.  

The combined effects of these disasters have left populations in both districts grappling with immediate survival needs, including evacuation, medical aid, and access to clean water.

field_reports.description:
The tensions between Iran and Israel have significantly intensified since June 13, 2025, with a series of missile strikes, drone attacks, and cross-border military actions marking the escalation. This worsening conflict has raised serious humanitarian concerns, especially for Iranian citizens living in provinces along the border.

The border between Pakistan and Iran spans approximately 909 kilometers, linking Pakistan’s Baluchistan province with Iran’s Sistan and Balochistan province. Should the situation continue to deteriorate, there is a growing risk of mass displacement, potentially leading to an influx of people into neighboring countries such as Pakistan.

Moreover, a considerable number of Pakistani nationals reside in Iran, including members of the business community, laborers, pilgrims, and students. Due to the ongoing hostilities and the closure of airspace, many Pakistanis have begun returning home through border crossings in Baluchistan. This trend is expected to accelerate in the days ahead.
field_reports.summary: PAK: Population Movement - 07-2025 - Population Movement: Iran-Pakistan June 2025

contacts.name: Raza Hyder
contacts.title: Deputy Director Migration & Displacement PRCS NHQ

field_reports.description:
Context: 

Since 1 November 2023, the Government of Pakistan has implemented the Illegal Foreigners Repatriation Program (IFRP), with intermittent pauses. In March 2025, authorities issued a notification advising Afghan Citizen Card (ACC) holders and undocumented Afghan nationals to voluntarily leave the country by 31 March 2025, thereafter deportations will commence with the effect from 1 April 2025. Between November 2023 and March 2025, a total of 842,429 Afghan nationals returned to Afghanistan. Of these, 40,677 individuals were deported while 51,196 returned voluntarily through facilitated processes.

Demographic information:

Currently, the Afghan population in Pakistan includes 1.43 million Proof of Registration (PoR) card holders, 800,700 ACC holders, and 143,900 unregistered members of registered families. The government estimates there are approximately 1.7 million undocumented Afghan nationals, although precise records are unavailable. Among the registered population, 444,439 individuals reside in refugee villages (camps), while 990,947 live outside these areas.

Impact of the Government Decison:

The ongoing repatriation policy is expected to primarily impact 800,700 ACC holders and an estimated 1.7 million undocumented Afghan nationals. Additionally, the situation may affect PoR cardholder families due to the presence of 143,900 unregistered members in their family compsotion, raising the possibility of family separations or forced return of otherwise registered households.

Anticipated number of Returnees in next 3 months:

According to the national contingency plan of the humanitarian actors, a high-risk scenario anticipates the return of approximately 739,000 Afghan nationals over the next three months.

Cross Border Movement  After the deadline:

Access to athentic and live cross border movement data remained challenging, however, UNHCR-IOM published the latest Flash update on 11th April, reflecting the return of 19,334 Afghans  through the Torkham, Ghulam Khan (located in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa), Chaman, Badini and Bahramcha (located in Balochistan) border crossing points to Afghanistan.

Return Process:

For the implementation of Illegal Forigner Repatriation Plan (IFRP) the government has established a process that includes establishment of 44 holding centers across four provinces of the country. Of the total holding centers 38 have been established in Punjab, one in Sindh, two in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), and three in Balochistan. Forced returnees are processed at the provincial holding centers before being transported to designated border crossing points, while voluntary returnees can directly approach the holding centers at crossing points.

Needs of the Returnees:

The National society's assesment reports and finding of coordination suggest needs of health services, first Aid, Food, Restoring familiy links and safe drinking water on Pakistan side of the border, both at crossing points and on-the route.
field_reports.summary: PAK: Population Movement - 04-2025 - Forced Repatriation of Afghan Nationals from Pakisrtan-April 2025

field_reports.description:
Pakistan is going through an intense monsoon season currently, leading to significant damages to infrastructure, casualties and injuries. This month of August has witnessed above normal rainfall and increase of 137% has been recorded till date. Geographically the 239% more rain than expected recorded in Baluchistan, Sindh 318%, Punjab 111% and KP 25% above normal.

This year the rain remained continued at different regions with some difference in intensity and intervals however the repeatedly affected the population. The latest spell which was forecasted by Pakistan Metrological department Starting from 26th to 30th August resulted in further damages and human losses.

The national disaster Management Authority data as of 2nd September reveals that since 1st July 2024, 306 people have been died, 584 people have been injured, 40 bridges have been damaged, 20653 houses damaged, 1100 livestock perished, a total of 119 KM roads at different location flooded away. The floods have also displaced approximately 9500 people in Sindh province. The damages caused by heavy rainfall and floods have increased the vulnerability of people and posing ongoing risks.

The latest spell of rain started from 26th of August caused further damages in communities already exposed by the previous floods and rainfall since July 2024, significantly increased their vulnerability. The latest spell resulted in damages, human loses and injuries which intensified on 31st August resulted in 13 deaths, 15 injuries and more than 1000 houses damaged on a single day. In addition, 2700 more house reported damaged in last 24 hours. Government has declared 13 districts as calamity hit district in Baluchistan and earlier emergency declared in Chitral district of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

Weather Forecast:

Met office informed that moist current from Bay of Bengal are likely to penetrate upper parts from 02nd September. A westerly wave is also likely to approach western parts of the country on 02nd September evening.

More rain have been predicted in the coming days with the possible impact of urban flooding, GLOF incidents, pluvial flood/inundation in low lying areas.
field_reports.summary: PAK: Flood - 08-2024 - Monsoon Rain/Floods in Pakistan August 2024

field_reports.description:
Weather Outlook and Impact:

Pakistan is expected to face a series of moderate to severe weather systems until April 29, as per assessments from the National Emergency Operations Centre (NEOC) and multiple weather models.

A recent surge of heavy rainfall has begun in Balochistan, affecting areas like Quetta, Chaman, and Chagi (Aminabad) since Wednesday.

The Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) has forecasted a combination of rain, windstorms, thunderstorms, and potential hailstorms across various regions including Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), Gilgit-Baltistan (GB), Azad Jammu and Kashmir (AJK), Islamabad, Punjab, Sindh, and Balochistan within the next 24 hours.

The forecast indicates that a significant weather system will enter Pakistan, leading to substantial rainfall and thunderstorms until April 22. Balochistan will bear the brunt from April 17 to April 19, followed by Punjab and Sindh from April 18 to April 19. Upper Punjab will experience impacts from April 18 to April 21, while KP, GB, and AJK will be affected from April 17 to April 22.

Subsequently, a weaker weather system is expected to arrive in Pakistan on April 23, bringing light rainfall and thunderstorms to specific areas until April 24. Balochistan and upper Punjab will see minor impacts from April 23 to April 24, while KP, GB, and AJK will also encounter effects. However, Sindh is not likely to be impacted during this period.

Impact and Casualties:

Storm-related incidents and lightning strikes since Friday have resulted in over 65 fatalities across the country. Balochistan government spokesperson Shahid Rind has confirmed these figures, with nine fatalities and nine injuries reported, highlighting the severity of the situation.

The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) Balochistan has reported heavy rains and flash floods causing urban flooding, resulting in eight deaths, eight injuries, and damaging infrastructure including 50 houses, a bridge, and two roads. In response, the government has declared a state of emergency and initiated resource mobilization to assist affected communities.

However, the extent of the damage is substantial, with 40 homes completely destroyed and 80 others partially damaged due to the intense downpour.

In KP, rain-related incidents have led to 32 deaths, 43 injuries, and significant damage to over 1,300 houses and 13 schools across various districts. PDMA Punjab has documented 13 fatalities, five injuries, and damage to crops and properties.

Looking ahead, a weather system is expected to bring heavy rainfall and thunderstorms until April 22, affecting multiple regions. Balochistan has experienced notable downpours, with Gwadar receiving the highest recorded rainfall of 80mm in a 24-hour period.

Potential Impacts and Advisories:

Heavy rainfall may trigger flash flooding in local nullahs/streams of several areas, including Dir, Swat, Chitral, Kohistan, Manshera, and the Kabul River tributaries in Gilgit-Baltistan and Kashmir. There's also a possibility of landslides in Upper Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Murree, Galiyat, Kashmir, and Gilgit Baltistan, particularly affecting vulnerable locations.

Windstorms, hailstorms, and lightning may cause damage to standing crops, electric poles, vehicles, and solar panels. Farmers in wheat-harvested areas are advised to manage their crops according to weather conditions, while tourists are advised to avoid unnecessary travel during the wet period.

Temperatures are expected to drop during the wet spell.

Additionally, at least 65 people have died in rain-related incidents across the country, with significant impacts observed in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (K-P), Punjab, and Balochistan, as detailed in media reports. Efforts are ongoing to provide relief and support to those affected, underscoring the urgent need for solidarity in addressing the aftermath of these weather events.

During this disaster, as per UN OCHA, approximately 77,000 individuals were affected, with 123 fatalities and 115 injuries reported.
field_reports.summary: PAK: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 04-2024 - El Niño-induced Pre-Monsoon Rains

results.name: PAK: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 04-2024 - El Niño-induced Pre-Monsoon Rains
results.summary:
From April 10th to April 15th, the National Weather Forecasting Center in Islamabad predicts a series of weather events in various regions of Pakistan. This includes rain, wind, and thunderstorms with intermittent breaks. On April 10th, a westerly wave is expected to enter the upper regions, followed by another potent wave on April 12th affecting most areas until April 15th.

In Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, regions such as Chitral, Dir, Swat, Abbottabad, Mansehra, and others will experience these weather conditions during this period, with occasional breaks. Similar conditions are anticipated in Waziristan, Kohat, Peshawar, and surrounding areas from April 12th onwards.

Gilgit-Baltistan and Kashmir should prepare for rain, wind, and thunderstorms (with snowfall in high mountains) from April 10th to April 15th, with breaks in between. Punjab, including Islamabad/Rawalpindi, Murree, and other areas, will also experience these conditions, particularly from April 12th onwards, with isolated windstorms and hailstorms expected from April 13th to April 15th.

Numerous casualties were reported due to severe weather conditions across three provinces, marking a grim situation in the affected areas:

Continuous heavy rainfall coupled with thunderstorms resulted in an additional 12 fatalities on Sunday, bringing the total death toll to at least 39 individuals across Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab, and Balochistan over recent days.

In Balochistan, Makran and surrounding areas witnessed ongoing rainfall, contributing to the province's death toll reaching 10 after two more casualties were reported from Kech district due to a lightning strike and a roof collapse incident on Sunday. Coastal towns like Pasni, Kech, and Panjgur districts, as well as Gwadar, faced substantial damages to infrastructure and transportation networks, causing restricted access from Quetta and other districts.

Power supply disruptions were severe, with uprooted electric pylons in Pasni and Panjgur leading to prolonged outages in Quetta and nearby regions. Gas supply issues and low pressure were also noted in various parts of the provincial capital and other cities.

Normal life and traffic were significantly impacted across approximately 25 districts of Balochistan, with incessant rains causing extensive damage to houses and roads, particularly in Pasni and Kech district where mud houses collapsed and link roads were washed away.

The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) reported five injuries from lightning strikes and assured the provision of medical care to the injured while planning financial assistance for the families of the deceased.

In Punjab, the death toll from lightning strikes rose to 21, with additional casualties reported from various districts, including Muzaffargarh, Rahim Yar Khan, and Bahawalpur.

Karachi also faced rain-related incidents, including traffic accidents resulting in six deaths, alongside concerns over lightning strikes and power outages. Chief Meteorologist Sardar Sarfaraz highlighted the increased risk of tornadoes and lightning due to a combination of sea breeze and cold winds.

Despite the weather system losing intensity, light rains were anticipated early on Monday, with Surjani Town recording the highest rainfall of 29 millimeters, followed by other areas like Nazimabad, Gulshan-i-Hadeed, and Keamari receiving significant amounts of rainfall.

field_reports.description:
Torrential rains have battered Gwadar district in Baluchistan, prompting the government to declare a state of emergency and designate it as a calamity-stricken area due to severe damage. The Meteorological Department forecasts worsening conditions, particularly in Gwadar, with heavy rainfall leading to floods and subsequent disruptions. On February 27th, 2024, torrential downpours caused flooding in Gwadar, submerging parts of the city and Sarbandar. Gwadar experienced continuous heavy rainfall for 24 hours, resulting in collapsed structures and submerged settlements around Jinnah Avenue. Other areas in Baluchistan, including Quetta, Dalbandin, Khuzdar, and Turbat, also experienced varying levels of precipitation. Gwadar was officially declared a 'Calamity Hit' area on February 28th, 2024. The Meteorological Department anticipates continued heavy rainfall until March 2nd, 2024. Damage assessments are ongoing in collaboration with the local administration, with approximately 10,000 households affected and challenges in accessing certain areas. The Prime Minister of Pakistan visited Gwadar, where the Deputy Commissioner briefed on the situation, highlighting damages to residences, livelihoods, sanitation, and water contamination.

avy rainfall and strong winds have affected north-western Pakistan, particularly Gwadar, in Baluchistan Province, over the last 48 hours, causing floods, torrential rain, and severe weather-related incidents resulting in casualties and damage. Provincial Disaster Management Authorities reported 35 deaths and 43 injuries. In Baluchistan Province, 5 deaths, 82 fully damaged houses, and 155 partially damaged houses were reported, with additional media reports indicating 50 injured individuals, around 700 damaged houses, and several blocked roads across both provinces. Reports from Gwadar district add 21 injured persons, 5 missing, and 950 displaced. Rescue operations are underway by the Army and civil armed forces. Drier conditions are expected over the next 24 hours across the entire country. 95% area has been affected due to rainwater.
Water has drained out from almost all villages. The district administration has deployed de-watering pumps with the support of PDMA in some areas where water is stagnant. In the initial phase, 12 x lifeboats were deployed, through which 2,164 people were rescued.
The official figures shared by the District and Tehsil Administration reveal that floodwater has been most affected:
o    Tehsil Jiwani and Sub Tehsil Suntsar 
o    Gwadar
o    Infrastructure and Property Losses
o    Electric Power Failure
o    Polio Campaign Suspension
o    Matric Exams Delayed
o    Internet and Cellular Connections
o    Connectivity Outages
o    Drinking Water Scarcity
o    3500 Houses full damaged
o    80 Boats Drowned
o    219 Livestock died.
o    14 roads were disconnected due to recent torrential rains which have been repaired and reconnected.
o    12 Areas Disconnected due to Dasht River.
Three far-flung villages disconnected have been provided relief items in collaboration with. Pak-Navy through Heli.
o    800 to 1000 people evacuated to their relative's houses.
o    Total Persons Rescued 355

Pakistan Army and Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) and district Administration rescued people in motor boats on the first day of the incident.  According to the information provided by concerned 900-950 people were rescued on day one through boats.
Pakistan Army has distributed cooked food and water bottles were dropped by helicopter amongst hundreds of trapped people who are not leaving their villages due to security risks.  They are now starting dry rashan (Food Parcels) to distribute.
The Gwadar district administration has declared a state of emergency in areas affected by the rain. DC Gwadar, alongside other officials, conducted visits to the affected regions and initiated rescue and relief operations.
PDMA has Deployed three teams equipped with 24 dewatering machines, 3 boats, 3 ambulances, and 1 rescue vehicle to the flood-affected regions of Baluchistan to provide relief and aid in evacuation efforts.
Caretaker Chief Minister Baluchistan, Mir Ali Mardan Khan Domki, has instructed the Provincial Disaster Management Authority Baluchistan to intensify relief operations in the rain-affected areas of Gwadar. This includes sending temporary shelters, tents, and other necessities, as requested by DC Gwadar.
PDMA Balochistan has also dispatched 1000 HHs relief supplies to areas impacted by the floods. Based on our meeting with district administration, other organizations are also planning to start their relief activities.

Suntsar is entirely cut off, making accessibility impossible. Conversely, Jiwani has clear accessibility. The Quetta-Gwadar-Karachi highway is operational, but the coastal highway from Gwadar to Jiwani and Pishukan is blocked, rendering those areas inaccessible. Zong network has weak signals in certain regions

results.name: PAK: Pluvial/Flash Flood - 02-2024 - Torrential Rainfall /Thunderstorm & Isolated Hailstorm
results.summary:
As per the Meteorological Department's predictions, specific regions, notably Gwadar, have encountered exacerbated conditions due to intense rainfall, leading to floods and subsequent disturbances. On February 27th, 2024, torrential rains triggered flooding in Gwadar, submerging several areas including Gwadar city and Sarabandan. The Commissioner of Makran verified that Gwadar witnessed prolonged heavy rainfall spanning nine hours, resulting in the collapse of structures and inundation of settlements around Jinnah Avenue.

The Meteorological Department reports that rainfall has been registered across various districts of Balochistan, with Gwadar recording the highest accumulation at 58 millimeters. Additionally, locations such as Quetta, Dalbandin, Khuzdar, and Turbat also witnessed varying degrees of precipitation.

The department anticipates ongoing rainfall starting from February 29th, 2024, bringing significant downpours to different parts of the province until March 2nd. The following matrix provides details concerning the incurred losses.

Potential Consequences:
• Inclement weather like rainstorms and snowfall may lead to road closures and landslides.
• Farmers are advised to adjust their agricultural activities following the forecasted weather conditions.
• Tourists and travelers are urged to exercise additional caution to prevent any unforeseen incidents during the predicted weather period.
• Members of the public are advised to seek shelter during rainstorms, windstorms, and lightning.
• Intense rainfall could result in flash floods, particularly in the Kech and Gwadar Districts.

field_reports.description:
Pakistan's Interior Minister, Sarfraz Bugti, has announced a stringent crackdown targeting "undocumented immigrants," including Afghan nationals, in Pakistan. Over recent years, a significant number of Afghans, fleeing the threat of persecution following the Taliban's takeover of Afghanistan in August 2021, sought refuge in Pakistan. Unfortunately, they have encountered many challenges, such as arbitrary detentions, arrests, and the constant specter of deportation. The extensive registration process has left the majority without Proof of Registration (PoR) or Afghan Citizen Card (ACC) credentials, which are vital for maintaining legal status as Afghan refugees in Pakistan. Many initially entered Pakistan with regular visas, which have since lapsed.

 

The UNHCR has issued a non-return advisory for Afghans residing outside their homeland following the Taliban's ascent to power. As per UNHCR data, there are over 3.7 million Afghans in Pakistan, who left Afghanistan due to both economic hardships and political instability. Regrettably, only 1.4 million of them possess formal registration.

"Afghans in Pakistan are fleeing persecution by the Taliban, leading them to live in highly precarious circumstances. They are forced to navigate complex procedures for refugee registration in Pakistan or endure protracted waits for potential relocation to other countries. Forcing their return to Afghanistan could place them in severe jeopardy."

"Afghans in Pakistan are fleeing persecution by the Taliban, leading them to live in highly precarious circumstances. They are forced to navigate complex procedures for refugee registration in Pakistan or endure protracted waits for potential relocation to other countries. Forcing their return to Afghanistan could place them in severe jeopardy."

"Afghans in Pakistan are in desperate need of increased support. The obstacles and delays they encounter in the process of registering as refugees or pursuing relocation to third countries have left them in legal limbo, rendering them even more susceptible to harassment and social stigma."

Current Updates:

Numerous organizations are actively formulating their official positions on this issue, with the intention of sharing them with the public in due course.

We have engaged with various stakeholders to evaluate the patterns of repatriation along the borders. Although there has been movement observed, it remains uncertain whether these movements are in response to the current circumstances or for other reasons.

Housing societies in Islamabad have issued notices to property owners who have rented their premises to Afghan migrants. The notices request the evacuation of Afghan nationals from these properties. It is emphasized that any discovery of illegal immigrants during the evacuation will result in legal action against the property owner. (Translation of the attached notice)

Interim Foreign Minister Jalil Abbas Jilani defended the order for all illegal immigrants, including 1.73 million Afghans, to depart, asserting that no other country permits illegal immigration, and this decision aligns with international norms.

Media reports have brought attention to the apprehension of illegal immigrants in Islamabad and Quetta.

Additionally, media reports have indicated that a delegation established by the Islamic Emirate to oversee the return of refugees from Pakistan has announced plans to establish a new refugee camp in the Lalapor district of Nangarhar.

We are available and ready to provide any necessary assistance.

field_reports.description:
During this monsoon season, numerous regions have been impacted by a combination of floods, landslides, and substantial rainfall.

On Saturday, the Sutlej River reached "exceptionally high levels" at the Ganda Singh Wala Barrage, evacuating hundreds of families from 72 villages in Kasur and Chunian. Tragically, during this flood event in Kasur, three individuals lost their lives while attempting to seek higher ground. 

The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) has issued a report indicating severe flooding in the Sutlej River. The outcome hinges on the water flow at Harike Headworks and Ferozepur Headworks. Currently, the water level at the Ganda Singh Wala Barrage has risen to 23 feet, with a flow rate of 269,000 cusecs. In Sulemanki, there is a moderate level of flooding with a flow rate of 83,072 cusecs. There is a looming threat of extremely high-level flooding at Head Sulemanki in the next 24 hours.

At Head Islam, the water flow has surged to 30,142 cusecs. The potential for extreme flooding at Head Islam is anticipated to commence on August 22. However, the water flow in Sindh, Jhelum, Chenab, and Ravi rivers remains normal.

The administrative authorities of the districts adjacent to the Sutlej River were put on high alert and measures had been implemented to restrict the movement of people in areas near Sutlej. Relevant deputy commissioners have been directed to reinforce the dykes along the Sutlej River.

Additionally, in a distinct incident, more than 100 buffaloes owned by a farmer in Usmanwala village, close to Ganda Singh, were carried away by the floodwaters while they were being relocated. Numerous individuals and animals found themselves trapped in the floodwaters because, despite early warnings of severe flooding during the past week, the authorities did not manage to evacuate them from their homes.

The evacuation status of various villages is as follows:

 Fully Evacuated Villages: Basti Saflian Wali, Masty Ki, Gati Killanjar, Basti Bhaggar

Partially Evacuated Villages: Chanda Singh, Dona Mobo Ke, Mobo Ke ,Bhiki Wind, Kamal Pura, Dhoop Sari, Bhuda Singh,Kaso Ki

Please go through the below details;

field_reports.description:
According to officials from the National Disaster Management Authority, there have been a total of 76 reported deaths in various rain-related incidents across Pakistan since the onset of the monsoon season on 25th June 2023. Additionally, 133 individuals have sustained injuries in multiple incidents. The majority of the fatalities occurred in Punjab and were primarily caused by electrocution and building collapses.

 In the provincial capital of Punjab, Lahore, there has been an unprecedented amount of rainfall, resulting in roads being transformed into waterways. This severe weather has left approximately 35% of the city without access to electricity and water this week. According to the Water and Sanitation Agency (WASA), the rainfall in Lahore has broken a 30-year record, with twelve out of sixteen monitoring points in the city recording rainfall exceeding 200 millimeters.

 

In Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, a tragic incident occurred in the Shangla district, where the bodies of eight children were recovered from a landslide on Thursday, as reported by the spokesperson of the emergency service Rescue 1122.

Please refer to the table below, extracted from the NDMA website, for a summary of the total rainfall data.

The Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) has issued a forecast for the next three days. According to their alert issued on 5th July, there is a prediction of widespread heavy to very heavy rainfall, with extremely heavy falls expected at scattered areas in the upper catchments of Rivers Sutlej, Ravi, Chenab, and partially Jhelum between 8th and 10th July 2023.

 

Additionally, the PMD has warned about the likelihood of severe thunderstorms and heavy rainfall in North and Northeastern Punjab, which may result in urban flooding in municipal areas and landslides in hilly regions.

 In Sindh, including cities like Karachi, Tharparkar, Sukkur, Larkana, Hyderabad, and Shaheed Benazir Abad, the Meteorological Office has forecasted potential thunderstorms and heavy rainfall. Furthermore, there is a possibility of thunderstorms in Northeastern Balochistan.

field_reports.description:
The Pakistan Meteorological Department (PMD) predicts more monsoon rains for Punjab and other parts of the country in the coming days. A weather system originating from the Bay of Bengal, along with a westerly trough affecting the upper regions, will persist until July 26th. The advisory warns of rain and thundershowers in various areas, including Islamabad, Rawalpindi, Lahore, Kashmir, Gilgit Baltistan, Murree, and Galliyat.

Residents in low-lying areas of twin cities, Peshawar, Gujranwala, and Lahore, should be cautious of possible urban flooding from July 22nd to 26th. Landslide warnings are also in place for vulnerable areas of Murree, Galliyat, Kashmir, Gilgit Baltistan, and hilly parts of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa during this period. Tourists visiting these regions are urged to remain vigilant and take necessary precautions.

The PMD's advisory highlights that monsoon currents of good intensity continue to penetrate into Sindh and the eastern parts of the country. As a result, dust-thunderstorm/rain with a few heavy falls are likely in specific districts, with occasional gaps till July 25th.

Areas including Tharparkar, Umerkot, Mirpurkhas, Badin, Thatta, Sujawal, Kambar Shahdadkot, Dadu, Jamshoro, Matiari, Hyderabad, Tando Allahyar, Tando Muhammad Khan, and Sanghar districts, as well as Karachi division, may experience heavy falls leading to waterlogging and localized urban flooding on July 23-24.

The advisory also warns that wind/dust storms may cause damage to loose structures like electric poles, solar panels, and trees. Farmers are advised to plan their activities considering the forecast, and the general public is urged to stay vigilant.

Currently, the majority of Pakistan is experiencing monsoon rains, but in the next 24 hours, there is a chance of thundercloud formation and rainfall across all provinces, including northeastern Punjab, Islamabad, Rawalpindi, Sindh, upper Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Kashmir, Gilgit-Baltistan, and scattered locations in northern, central, and southern Punjab. Coastal areas, including Karachi, may expect continuous rainfall, humid evenings, and occasional light clouds during the evening hours. However, the likelihood of rainfall in the upcoming days is low.

Rainfall is expected in various areas of Punjab, eastern Sindh, Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Kashmir, Gilgit-Baltistan, and Balochistan in Pakistan, particularly in central and northern regions, due to westerly winds coming from the western region.

Over the course of last month, starting from June 25, 2023, at least 133 people, including 55 children and 21 females, have lost their lives in weather-related incidents caused by heavy monsoon rains across Pakistan. During the same period, 215 people were injured. The province of Punjab and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa witnessed the highest number of fatalities, which were primarily due to electrocution, building collapses, landslides, and drowning. field_reports.description:
The severe cyclonic storm named "BIPARJOY" in the northeast Arabian Sea has weakened after crossing the Indian Gujarat coast near Jakhau port. It is now a severe cyclonic storm and is currently located at Latitude 23.8°N and Longitude 69.4°E, approximately 200km east-southeast of Keti Bandar, 180km southeast of Thatta, and 270km east of Karachi. The maximum sustained surface winds associated with the storm are between 80-100 Km/hour. The sea conditions in the Northeast Arabian Sea are very rough, with wave heights reaching 10-12 feet. The system is expected to further weaken into a cyclonic storm by noon today and subsequently into a depression by evening.

Under the influence of this system, the following impacts are expected:

Widespread rain and thunderstorms, with some heavy to very heavy falls, accompanied by squally winds of 80-100 Km/hour, are likely in Sujawal, Badin, Tharparker, and Umerkot districts. Additionally, heavy rainfall is expected in Thatta and Mirpurkhas districts today and tomorrow.
In Karachi, Hyderabad, Tando Muhammad Khan, Tando Allayar, Shaheed Benazirabad, and Sanghar districts, there will be dust storms, thunderstorms, and rain with a few moderate falls. These conditions will be accompanied by gusty winds of 30-50 Km/hour.
Squally winds may cause damage to vulnerable structures such as kutcha houses in Thatta, Sujawal, Badin, Tharparker, and Umerkot districts.
A storm surge of 2-2.5 meters (6-8 feet) is expected along Keti Bandar and the surrounding areas.
The sea conditions along the Sindh-Makran coast are likely to be rough to very rough, with a 2-meter tide.
Fishermen are advised not to venture into the open sea until the system has passed by June 17.
Possible impacts in the coming days include:

The storm is likely to approach the southeast Sindh coast, bringing widespread wind, dust, thunderstorms, and heavy to extremely heavy rainfall accompanied by squally winds of 80-100 Km/hour, gusting up to 120 Km/hour in Thatta, Sujawal, Badin, Tharparker, Mirpurkhas, and Umerkot districts from June 13 to 17.
Karachi, Hyderabad, Tando Muhammad Khan, Tando Allayar, Shaheed Benazirabad, and Sanghar districts may experience dust storms, thunderstorms, rain with a few heavy falls, and squally winds of 60-80 Km/hour from June 14 to 16. The high-intensity squally winds may cause damage to vulnerable structures, including kutcha houses and solar panels. A storm surge of 3-3.5 meters (8-12 feet) is expected at the landfall point, specifically Keti Bandar and the surrounding areas, which could lead to the inundation of low-lying settlements.
field_reports.summary: PAK: Cyclone - 2023-06 - Tropical Cyclone (BIPARJOY) Formed over Southeast Arabian Sea

results.name: PAK: Cyclone - 2023-06 - Tropical Cyclone (BIPARJOY) Formed over Southeast Arabian Sea
results.summary:
The Depression over the southeast Arabian Sea has strengthened and is now a Cyclonic Storm named "BIPARJOY." It is currently located at Latitude 12.3°N and Longitude 66.0°E, approximately 1420km south of Karachi. The maximum sustained surface winds around the center of the storm are 60-70 Km/hour, with gusts up to 80 Km/hour. The environmental conditions, including a sea surface temperature of 30-32°C, low vertical wind shear, and upper-level divergence, are favorable for further intensification. The system is expected to become a Severe Cyclonic Storm within the next 24 to 36 hours and continue moving in the north/northwest direction.

The low-pressure area over the Southeast Arabian Sea has developed into a Depression, which is now a strong LPA. It is positioned near Latitude 11.5°N and Longitude 66.0°E, about 1500km south of Karachi. The environmental conditions, including a sea surface temperature of 30-31°C, low vertical wind shear, and upper-level divergence, are conducive for further intensification. The system is likely to progress into a Tropical Storm within the next 18 to 24 hours while moving in the north/northwest direction.

At present, none of the coastal areas in Pakistan are under threat from the cyclonic storm. The Pakistan Meteorological Department's cyclone warning center in Karachi is closely monitoring the system and will provide updates accordingly.

field_reports.description:
A magnitude 6.8 earthquake with 180 Km depth, rattled much of Pakistan and Afghanistan on Tuesday, sending panicked residents fleeing from homes and offices and frightening people in remote villages. At least nine people died & 47 injured with 19 x partially collapsed houses mainly in few districts of Khyber PakhtonKhawah Province of Pakistan.

The situation was closely monitored by the control rooms of District Disaster Managment Authorties & Provincial DMAs to gather information. However, no such damage report is reported in any other province.

field_reports.description:
As massive floods across Pakistan have so far claimed at least 830 so far, the government on Tuesday decided to launch an international appeal seeking funds for relief and rehabilitation of flood-hit people and restoration of damaged infrastructure. Deadly flash floods and torrential rains continue to ravage many parts of Balochistan, with no rail and road link between Quetta and rest of the country despite all-out efforts for past several days, the provincial government called upon the Centre to provide a special package of Rs60 billion for repair of infrastructure and rehabilitation of flood-hit families. Officials put the death toll across the province at 225. The rains also badly affected Sindh, Punjab and KP Provinces. The government of Sindh declared 23 districts as calamity-hit due to the magnitude of damages caused by torrential rains and flooding.

The flood badly affected the infrastructure and so far  319,450 houses damaged across the country. In addition, 504,321 livestock has been lost and more than 2886.9 km of roads and 129 bridges have been damaged.

The death toll from more than five weeks of monsoon rains and flash flooding across country has reached 357, with those killed including 140 children, according to authorities. Since mid-June, the deluge has swollen rivers, damaged highways and bridges and disrupting traffic. According to the Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA), 111 people in Balochistan have lost their lives in the downpours since so far. Additionally, more than 6,000 houses were damaged of which 3,000 were completely destroyed, the authority said in a statement issued today. According to reports the most affected provinces are that of Balochistan, KP, and Punjab where army is assisting the local administration in rescue and relief operation. Accordingly to NDMA, approximately 19,450 houses are partially damaged while 6,042 are fully damaged. Met office predicted more rain in coming week which may worsen the situation.

At least 26 people were killed in rain-related incidents in Sindh after ruthless monsoon showers battered Karachi and other parts of the province on Monday 11th July, the Sindh Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) said .Heavy rains have been lashing multiple areas of the country since last week. According to authorities, the downpour has wreaked havoc in Balochistan as well where the local administration has geared up to deal with the emergency situation. As per NDMA reports the monsoon rains across the country which began on June 14 — have claimed 150 lives so far of which 65 were reported in Balochistan. Following the deaths of dozens of people, the Balochistan government declared Quetta a disaster-struck area and imposed a state of emergency in the provincial capital. According to the Balochistan Disaster Management Authority, Qila Saifullah, Zhob, Pishin and Harnai districts have been the most affected by the rains, whereas flood conditions have also been reported in Muslim Bagh, Qamaruddin, and Khushnoob. There were flash floods overnight in several villages of Khushnoob, and a link bridge was swept away, making it difficult for rescue workers to reach the affected people. The Chaman administration has said that more than 70 houses were affected by the floods in Badizai and Torkhel areas. In KP, Chitral – Mastuj road was blocked at Rashun after River Yarkhoon started eroding land and houses at Shader Area of Rashun. The flood water badly affected some house. In GB, at least five people have been killed in Sherqila village of Ghizer district after being swept away in flash floods.

Heavy rains have been lashing multiple areas of the country since the start of this week. results.name: Pakistan: Monsoon Floods
results.summary:
Calling the incessant monsoon rains a “climate-induced humanitarian crisis of epic proportions”, the Government of Pakistan on 25 August 2022 officially declared a ‘national emergency’ in light of the rain-induced floods, which have killed 1,700 people already, including 632 children since 14 June.

 

Pakistan Red Crescent reached 267,358 people with emergency lifesaving assistance, coordinating with the local authorities, UN, and other agencies to cover the larger needs across the country.

One-third of Pakistan’s territory and around 33 million people have been impacted by the floods in 84 calamity-declared districts, of which 32 are in Balochistan, 23 in Sindh, 17 in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa (KP), 9 in Gilgit-Baltistan (GB) and 3 in Punjab. The number of people affected represents the entire population of Sweden, Finland, Norway, Denmark, Ireland, and Slovakia combined.

Between 26 September and 2 October, almost 25 per cent of the country was still underwater and there are still about 15 million individuals who could be affected by flooding or live nearby. In KP, waters have receded and people are slowly returning to their home areas in need of early recovery support. In Sindh and Balochistan receding has also begun, but especially in parts of Sindh, the emergency continues and flooding may still occur in the southern parts. According to provincial authorities, completion of the receding of waters will take 3-6 more months.

More than 2 million houses have been damaged or destroyed leaving approximately 8 million people displaced and approximately 600,000 people living in relief camps. Almost 88 per cent of the destruction of houses occurred in Sindh, which has borne also the brunt of the damage to roads and bridges, leaving people stranded in many places.

Destruction of water, sanitation and health facilities has caused a heightened risk of a public health crisis. Assessments are illustrating increased trends in water- and vector-borne diseases, with outbreaks of diarrheal diseases, measles, skin infections, respiratory tract infections, malaria, and dengue, particularly in Sindh and Balochistan. Access to already limited health services is constrained further due to the damage to over 1,400 health facilities across Sindh and Balochistan.

Access to safe drinking water, sanitation and hygiene are of serious concern. In the newest projections, more than 8.6 million people will face crisis or emergency levels of food insecurity (IPC 3+) mainly in Sindh and Balochistan. The acute food insecurity in the coming months is driven by the destruction of crops, agricultural land, livelihood assets, and livestock.

The priority needs are preventative public health interventions, including rehabilitation of water and sanitation facilities and hygiene campaigns for the prevention of disease transmission, increased access to health services, maternal and child health care interventions, shelter items and winterization support in the cold areas, and assistance to meet basic needs and to recover livelihoods. The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies Emergency Appeal is prioritizing humanitarian response for the heavily affected populations in KP, Balochistan and Sindh provinces.

The aim of this Emergency Appeal is to support the priority humanitarian response for the heavily affected populations in the flood-hit regions of Pakistan. This also includes a focus on the response capacity and readiness of the National Society and affected communities.

field_reports.description: The long hot summer is about to get even hotter, and future summers even worse. Just after a scorching March and April in many parts of the country, the Met office again forecast “severe heatwave conditions” across Pakistan in first half of May. Some areas remained between 7°C to 9°C above normal while others between 6°C to 8°C. Among possible impacts of the very dry and hot weather, according to the Met office press release, is water stress on reservoirs, orchards, vegetable farms, etc and “farmers are advised to manage crop water accordingly”. Grim tidings have also emerged from just published research in which top climate scientists say that South Asia is yet to experience the hottest part of the year. That would be a catastrophic event “likely to kill thousands” in India and Pakistan, according to the lead scientist at a climate science research non-profit. These extreme events will not be outliers. A landmark report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, has predicted “intensity and frequency of hot extremes, such as warm days, warm nights, and heatwaves; and decreases in the intensity and frequency of cold extremes, such as cold days and cold nights” across Asia. However, things will be worse in South Asia where “more intense heatwaves of longer durations and occurring at a higher frequency are projected”. The current severe heat wave is a wakeup call that intergovernmental agency action, preparedness, and community outreach are needed to save lives.

Tens of thousands of people thronged Punjab’s hill town of Murree in order to enjoy the snowfall. However, it turned to disaster when a large number of vehicles stranded in snow on Friday night and 22 people died. The heavy snowstorm blocked the roads and vehicle could not moved. Resultantly, Eight of them froze to death in their cars and others probably died from asphyxiation after inhaling exhaust fumes in snow-bound vehicles.

The westerly weather system of strong winds entered the country on January 3rd, 2022 that caused an unprecedented rain fall in Baluchistan and specifically in District Gwadar which received almost 100mm of rains. The initial reports revealed that Jiwnai, Pishukan, Surbandar and Ormara are the worst affected areas of the districts. Similarly, the rain water also created havoc in District Chaman and Kech. The reports suggested that infrastructure including bridges, communication channel and electric supply is heavily affected by the flood inundation. Parts of the affected districts were inaccessible till date due to destruction of the connecting bridges from Karachi to Gwadar and Quetta to Chaman. The transportation services in the affected districts were restricted and number of passengers were stuck on the roads in most parts of flooded areas of districts Gwadar.

The current dengue epidemic has caused to date over 19580 confirmed cases and over 300 deaths in Pakistan. Punjab and KPK provinces are badly hit, which led to the recent opening of a 280 bedded dengue field hospital in Lahore. Rawalpindi the worst-hit city in Punjab after Lahore, where dengue patients are reported on a daily basis. 
Adjoining Rawalpindi is the Capital city of Islamabad, which is also caught in the clutches of dengue virus and according to the District Health Officer (DHO) Dr Zaeem Zia, the total number of dengue cases reached 1,342. The current weather is consider as favorable for Dengue outbreak and cases are expected to increases in coming days.

The 5.7M earthquake hit at 03AM in the morning local time as people were sleeping. At least 20 persons are reported dead including six children and approximately 300 injured with many rushed to the hospital in critical condition and fractures. Approximately a hundred mud houses have reported collapsed leaving hundreds of persons without shelter. Much of the damage seems to have taken place in Hernai district according to local authority interviewed in news. Hernai is a fairly remote, mountainous city and the area hosts a lot of coal mines. Health workers and rescue efforts were hampered by a power cut caused by the earthquake – hospital workers reported having to do with torches for light. The earthquake also resulted in landslides in many areas which created hinderance in the rescue efforts.

results.name: Regional Population Movement - Afghanistan | Preparedness and Response
results.summary:
The evolving situation in Afghanistan is increasingly creating new potential drivers and triggers for cross-border displacement. The 2021 Afghanistan Humanitarian Needs Overview identified 18.4 million people in need of humanitarian assistance with 6.3 million being in extreme or catastrophic severity of needs; this figure is now likely to have increased due to the recent events in country. The situation remains uncertain in Afghanistan and may evolve rapidly.

Afghanistan faces an alarming humanitarian emergency and a worsening economic crisis, both likely to be further compounded by the approaching winter season. Almost half the population faces colossal humanitarian needs wrought by a combination of crises: displacement, devastation of COVID-19 pandemic, drought, acute food shortages, a fractured health system, poor access to services, and restrictive social norms. More than 558,000 Afghans have been internally displaced by the conflict since January 2021, 80 per cent of these newly internally displaced are women and children.

According to the drought declaration by the Afghanistan government of 22 June 2021, the country’s wheat crop will be reduced by nearly two million tons, and more than three million livestock are in danger of perishing due to a lack of fodder and water. IPC new projections for the period June – November 2021 estimates that, 2,742,741 Afghans are likely to be classified in Phase 4 (catastrophic) in terms of Food Insecurity and 6,719,607 in Phase 3 (emergency). The compounding impacts of drought and conflict which escalated in July and the first half of August have exacerbated the hard living conditions in a country that is also grappling with COVID-19 and poverty. Access to banking services has been severely constrained, with cashflow crippled. Collapse of Afghanistan’s economy would result in catastrophic consequences for vulnerable Afghans, including potentially fueling cross-border movements for economic reasons.

Therefore, based on analysis of the ongoing social, economic, political and security situation in Afghanistan, it is assessed that a further political and humanitarian deterioration in the country is likely to result in new population movements to neighbouring countries. A potential worst-case scenario – utilized by the UNHCR and inter-agency partners - envisages the arrival of an additional 515,000 Afghan refugees into neighbouring countries before the end of 2021.

Any major population movement will require an immediate and sustained humanitarian intervention in neighbouring countries. This will include critical life-saving humanitarian assistance at border points and in designated sites in coordination with respective authorities.

There are up to six million Afghans living outside of Afghanistan – in Europe, Asia Pacific and the Middle East - following several decades of instability in the country. New arrivals in 2021 will join more than 2.2 million registered refugees who have fled previous waves of insecurity, instability and violence to neighbouring countries. There are a further 3 million Afghans with varying status including many irregular migrants, who have been hosted in the Islamic Republic of Iran and the Islamic Republic of Pakistan over the past four decades. It will be important to maintain humanitarian assistance and protection for both new arrivals, and those previously displaced, as well as host communities.

Beyond the scope of this Emergency Appeal, there may also be onward movements and humanitarian needs in secondary countries, with Afghans taking routes to Turkey, Greece and the Western Balkans region. It will be critical to both monitor these trends and developments, as well as to be prepared and ready to provide increased principled humanitarian assistance and protection along existing migratory routes to those on the move– irrespective of their status – and to host communities in secondary countries.

field_reports.description:
On June 26, 2023, at approximately 14:00, a flash flood occurred in Mollaişığli village of Ismayilli district. The reason for this flood was heavy rains that happened frequently recently. As a result of the flood, the main infrastructures of the village and 65 households were heavily damaged.

The basement of the village secondary school was completely flooded and the school building was heavily damaged. The flood significantly damaged the buildings of 25 houses and the living area of 40 houses. As a result of the flood, about 160 tons of grain, 7 cows, 18 sheep, 650 poultry, 0.80 ha of almond orchard, 3 village springs and one car were completely destroyed. The main highway into the village is closed.

This year, the effect of flooding across the affected states has been devastating. Presently all the regions across the country (North-Central, North-East, North- West, South - East, South-South and South-West) already reported challenges regarding floods causing displacement, destruction of houses and farm lands/crops thereby exposing people to extreme vulnerability and hardship. 
Being able to accurately and quickly model flooding can help predict and prepare for the risks. 
The year 2020 is not exceptional as between the months of June and September at least 450,000 hectares (1.2 million acres)  were destroyed in Kebbi the country’s main rice- growing State, according to Mohammed Sahabi, the State chairman of the Rice Farmers Association of Nigeria. At Kende community  in Kebbi, the Sokoto River stood at 5.03 metres as of 30th August. The Sokoto joins the river Niger just south of Kende. The Niger at the Jidere Bode measuring station in Kebbi jumped from 1.4 metres in mid July to 5.74 metres by late August. Also farmers in eleven other states i.e Bauchi, Delta, FCT, Jigawa, Niger, Ogun, Ondo, Taraba, Yobe and Zamfara already reported damage. Source: www.bloomberg.coflood 
Due to opening of Kainji , Jebba, and Shiroro Dams on the 11th of September, flood also occurred in Kwara, a state in the North Central region. Several Houses, farmland/ Livestock, infrastructures and many other properties were seriously affected. Well over 15,000 households across 357 communities of the state are estimated to have been affected by the incidents that also destroyed farmlands and human dwellings worth billions of naira. In the wake of the floods, over 100,000 hectares of rice, maize and millet farms in a fishing and agrarian settlement in Pategi LGA were destroyed
Nigerian Red Cross Branches in those states aforementioned have deployed staff and Volunteers to assist in evacuation of those affected, First Aid to the injured, community based flood sensitization and Advocacy to relevant stakeholders.

Heavy Monsoon rains continue in different part of the country resulted in flash and urban flooding. The Monsoon rains so far killed 163 people across the country while 101 reported injured. The floods also damaged houses and other infrastructure while standing crops also heavily affected. The first heavy spell of rains  on 6-7 Aug. created flood situation in Sindh and Baluchistan Province, while another more heavy Monsoon spell which started on 20th Aug. 2020 and still continue with intervals resulted urban flooding in Sindh (mostly in Karachi and Hyderabad division), floods in Baluchistan and flash flooding in parts of KP including district Swat and Kohistan.
